facts.text: Appeals arise from judgments and orders of the Bombay High Court dated July 6, 1954 in Special Civil Applications Nos. 393, 395, 409 and 632 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgments and orders of the Bombay High Court dated July 6, 1954, in Special Civil Applications Nos. 393, 395, 409 and 632 of 1954 July 19, 1954, in Special Civil Application No. 1205 of 1954 and July 30, 1954, in Special Civil Application No. 1309 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: July 30, 1954, in Special Civil Application No. 1309 of 1954. Purshottam Trikamdas, V. M. Limaye, E. Udayaratnam and S. S. Shukla, for the appellants.

facts.text: Certificate granted by the Bombay High Court for these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: These six appeals on a certificate granted by the Bombay High Court raise a companymon question as to the companystitutionality of the Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, No. XLII of 1953,

facts.text: Judgment delivered by WANCHOO J. on October 3, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. October 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-These six appeals on a certificate granted by the Bombay High Court raise a companymon question

facts.text: Appellants hold personal inams confirmed by Bombay Acts Nos. 11 and VII of 1863.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants hold personal inams which are companyered by Bombay Acts Nos. 11 and VII of 1863. The Act was attacked on a number of grounds in the High Court

facts.text: Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, No. XLII of 1953 challenged on constitutionality.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was attacked on a number of grounds in the High Court of which only two have been urged before us, namely,  i  that the property which has been dealt with under the Act

facts.text: Appellants contended that the property dealt with under the Act is not an estate.

anchor.surface_text: namely,  i  that the property which has been dealt with under the Act is number an estate and  ii  that numbercompensation has been provided in the Act for taking away the property

facts.text: Appellants contended that no compensation provided in the Act for taking away their property.

anchor.surface_text: ii  that numbercompensation has been provided in the Act for taking away the property of the appellants The writ petitions were opposed by the State of Bombay

facts.text: State of Bombay contended that the Act is protected under Article 31A of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petitions were opposed by the State of Bombay and the main companytention on its behalf was that the Act was protected under Art. 31-A of the Constitution.

facts.text: Act No. 11 of 1863 extended to certain parts of the Presidency of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with the two points raised before us, we should like briefly to refer to the rights which holders of personal inams had by virtue of Bombay Acts Nos. II and VII of 1863. Act No. 11 extended to certain parts

facts.text: Under Act No. 11 of 1863, holders consented to terms for perpetual land holding paying nazrana and quit-rent equal to one-fourth assessment.

anchor.surface_text: It laid down that if such holders of lands companysented to submit to the terms and companyditions prescribed in the Act in preference to being obliged to prove their title to the exemption enjoyed by them, the Provincial Government would be prepared to finally authorise and guarantee the companytinuance, in perpetuity, of the said land to the said holders, their heirs and assigns upon the said terms and subject to the said companyditions. The main provision of the Act in this respect was that such holders of land would be entitled to keep their lands in perpetuity subject to payment of  i  a fixed annual payment as nazrana in companymutation of all claims of the Crown in respect of succession and transfer which shall be calculated at the rate of one anna for each rupee of assessment and  ii  a quit-rent equal to one-fourth of the assessment.

facts.text: Holders under Act 11 paid five annas in the rupee of full assessment and retained eleven annas.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the main right which the holders of lands got by Act 11 was that they held their lands on payment of one-fourth of the assessment instead of full assessment plus further one-sixteenth of the assessment thus they paid in all five annas in the rupee of the full assessment and retained eleven annas in the rupee for themselves.

facts.text: Act No. VII of 1863 dealt with holders in remaining parts of Presidency, quit-rent two annas per rupee.

anchor.surface_text: Act No. VII dealt with similar holders of lands in the remaining parts of the Presidency of Bombay, and made similar provisions with this difference that such holders of lands were to pay two annas for each rupee of the assessment as quit-rent under s. 6. Thus those who came under Act VII paid only two annas in the rupee of the assessment and retained fourteen annas in the rupee for themselves.

facts.text: Section 2(c) of the Act defines inamdar as holder of personal inam.

anchor.surface_text: We number turn to the provisions of the Act. By s. 2 c  inamdar is defined as a holder of personal inam and includes any person lawfully holding under or through him.

facts.text: Section 4 of the Act extinguishes all personal inams and subsisting rights therein.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 extinguishes all personal inams and save as expressly provided by or under the provisions of the Act, all rights legally subsisting on the said date in respect of such personal inams were also extinguished

facts.text: Section 5 makes inam lands liable to full land-revenue as per Bombay Land Revenue Code.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 provides that all inam villages or inam lands are and shall be liable to the payment of land- revenue in accordance with the provisions of the Code or the rules made thereunder and the provisions of the Code and the rules relating to unalienated lands shall apply to such lands.

facts.text: Inamdar becomes occupant liable for full land-revenue under Section 5.

anchor.surface_text: It further provides that an inamdar in respect of the inam land in his actual possession or in possession of a person holding from him other than an inferior holder  subject to an exception which we shall mention just number  would be primarily liable to the State Government for the payment of land-revenue due in respect of such land held by him

facts.text: Section 7 vests certain lands like public roads, water bodies in State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 then vests certain lands like public roads, paths and lanes, the bridges, ditches, dikes and fences, the bed of the sea and harbours, creeks below high water mark and of rivers, streams, nallas, lakes, wells and tanks, and all canals, water-courses, all standing and flowing water, all unbuilt village sites, all waste lands and all uncultivated lands

facts.text: Section 10 provides compensation for extinguishment under Section 7.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 provides for companypensation for extinguishment of rights under s. 7 while s. 11 gives a right of appeal from the order of the Collector under s. 10.

facts.text: Section 17(5) states no compensation for lands made subject to full assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Sub- section  5  of s. 17 however says that numberhing in this section shall entitle any person to companypensation on the ground that any inam village or inam land which was wholly or partially exempt from the payment of land revenue has been under the provisions of this Act made subject to the payment of full assessment

facts.text: Court held that 'estate' in Art. 31A includes inam.

anchor.surface_text: It will be, clear from the definition of the word estate in Art. 31-A 2  a  that it specifically includes an inam within it. As such it would be in our opinion idle to companytend that inams are number estates within the meaning of the expression estate

facts.text: Right to retain difference between full assessment and quit-rent is a right in an estate under Art. 31A.

anchor.surface_text: Inams being estates, the right of the inamdar to retain part of the full assessment over and above the quit-rent payable to the Government arises because he holds the inam-estate. The right therefore can be numberhing more than a right in an estate.

facts.text: Act protected under Art. 31A from attacks under Arts. 14, 19, 31.

anchor.surface_text: The Act therefore when it extinguishes or modifies the rights of inamdars in the inam estates is clearly protected by Art. 31-A.

facts.text: No compensation required under Art. 31 due to protection by Art. 31A.

anchor.surface_text: It is how- ever clear that Art. 31-A saves the Act from any attack under Art. 31 which is the only Article providing for companypensation.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberforce in these appeals and they are hereby dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: whether the Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, No. XLII of 1953 is constitutional

anchor.surface_text: raise a companymon question as to the companystitutionality of the Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, No. XLII of 1953,  hereinafter called the Act  and will be disposed of by this judgment. The appellants hold personal inams

issues.text: whether the property which has been dealt with under the Act is an estate

anchor.surface_text: i that the property which has been dealt with under the Act is number an estate and ii that numbercompensation has been provided in the Act for taking away the property of the appellants The writ petitions were opposed by the State of Bombay and the main companytention on its behalf was that the Act was protected under Art. 31-A of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether compensation has been provided in the Act for taking away the property of the appellants

anchor.surface_text: ii that numbercompensation has been provided in the Act for taking away the property of the appellants The writ petitions were opposed by the State of Bombay and the main companytention on its behalf was that the Act was protected under Art. 31-A of the Constitution. Before we deal with the two points raised before us, we should like briefly to refer to the rights which holders of personal inams had by virtue of Bombay Acts Nos. II and VII of 1863. Act No. 11 extended to certain parts of the Presidency of Bombay and dealt with holders of lands in those parts who were holding lands wholly or partially exempt from the payment of government land-revenue.

issues.text: whether the Act was protected under Art. 31-A of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: that the Act was protected under Art. 31-A of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the right of the inamdar to appropriate to himself the difference between the full assessment and the quit-rent is a right in an estate under Art. 31A

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it is urged that what ss. 4 and 5 extinguish is the right of the inamdar to appropriate to himself the difference between the full assessment and the quit-rent, and this is number an estate within the meaning of Art, 31 A of the Constitution. The relevant provisions in Art. 31-A for present purposes aref these- 31-A  1 -Notwithstanding anything companytained in art. 13, numberlaw providing for-  a  the acquisition by the State of any estate or of any rights therein or the extinguishment or modification of any such rights, or

issues.text: whether the Act provides for compensation and is therefore ultra vires Art. 31

anchor.surface_text: The next companytention is that the Act does number provide for companypensation and is therefore ultra vires in view of Art. We find, however, that the Act has provided for companypensation under s. 10 so far as that part of inam lands which are vested in the State by s. 7 are companycerned. Further s. 17 provides for companypensation in a possible case where anything has been left out by s. 7 and the inamdar is entitled to companypensation for it. It is true that by sub s.  5  of s. 17 numbercompensation is to be paid for the loss to the inamdar of what he used to get because of the difference between the quit-rent and the full assessment.

anchor.surface_text: It is however clear that Art. 31-A saves the Act from any attack under Art. 31 which is the only Article providing for compensation.

holdings.text: It will be, clear from the definition of the word estate in Art. 31-A 2  a  that it specifically includes an inam within it. As such it would be in our opinion idle to companytend that inams are number estates within the meaning of the expression estate for the purpose of Art. 31-A.

anchor.surface_text: It will be, clear from the definition of the word estate in Art. 31-A 2  a  that it specifically includes an inam within it. As such it would be in our opinion idle to companytend that inams are number estates within the meaning of the expression estate for the purpose of Art. 31-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of definition in Art. 31A(2)(a) explicitly including 'inam' as estate.

holdings.text: The Act specifically deals with inams and would thus be obviously protected under Art. 31-A from any attack under Art. 14, Art. 19 or Art. 31.

anchor.surface_text: The Act specifically deals with inams and would thus be obviously protected under Art. 31-A from any attack under Art. 14, Art. 19 or Art. 31.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since inams are estates and Act deals with them, Art. 31A protection applies against fundamental rights challenges.

holdings.text: Inams being estates, the right of the inamdar to retain part of the full assessment over and above the quit-rent payable to the Government arises because he holds the inam-estate. The right therefore can be numberhing more than a right in an estate.

anchor.surface_text: Inams being estates, the right of the inamdar to retain part of the full assessment over and above the quit-rent payable to the Government arises because he holds the inam-estate. The right therefore can be numberhing more than a right in an estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right derives from holding the estate; inherently a right in an estate.

holdings.text: Besides the definition of the expression rights in Art. 31-A 2  b  makes the position clear beyond all doubt, for it provides that the rights in relation to an estate would include any rights or privileges in respect of land revenue

anchor.surface_text: Besides the definition of the expression rights in Art. 31-A 2  b  makes the position clear beyond all doubt, for it provides that the rights in relation to an estate would include any rights or privileges in respect of land revenue .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusive definition in Art. 31A(2)(b) covers rights/privileges in respect of land revenue.

holdings.text: Besides, it is clear that the right in question falls under s. 3 5  of the Code and as such also it is an estate under Art.31-A.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it is clear that the right in question falls under s. 3 5  of the Code and as such also it is an estate under Art.31-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right falls under Bombay Land Revenue Code s.35, hence qualifies as estate under Art.31A.

holdings.text: The companytention of the appellants therefore that inams dealt with by the Act are number companyered by the expression estate in Art. 31-A fails. Their further companytention that their right to retain the difference between full assessment and quit-rent is number a right in an estate also fails.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants therefore that inams dealt with by the Act are not covered by the expression estate in Art. 31-A fails. Their further contention that their right to retain the difference between full assessment and quit-rent is not a right in an estate also fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects both petitioner contentions based on prior interpretations of Art.31A.

holdings.text: The Act therefore when it extinguishes or modifies the rights of inamdars in the inam estates is clearly protected by Art. 31-A.

anchor.surface_text: The Act therefore when it extinguishes or modifies the rights of inamdars in the inam estates is clearly protected by Art. 31-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Art.31A to Act's provisions on estates and rights therein.

holdings.text: It is however clear that Art. 31-A saves the Act from any attack under Art. 31 which is the only Article providing for companypensation.

anchor.surface_text: It is however clear that Art. 31-A saves the Act from any attack under Art. 31 which is the only Article providing for compensation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.31A protection overrides Art.31 compensation requirement despite no compensation for certain rights.

holdings.text: In this view of the matter the companystitutionality of the Act cannot be assailed on the ground that it provides numbercompanypensation for extinction of certain rights.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the constitutionality of the Act cannot be assailed on the ground that it provides no compensation for extinction of certain rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of Art.31A protection resolves constitutionality challenge.
